facts.text: Nagappa (father of Pallaniappa) made a will on June 10, 1934, disposing certain properties in favour of persons including his wife, and giving the residue absolutely to Pallaniappa, appointing him executor.
Will stated most properties were testator's exclusive self-acquired property, but made with consent of son Pallaniappa.
Nagappa died in July 1934; Pallaniappa obtained probate and possessed residue after legacies.
All properties left by Nagappa were joint family properties of Nagappa and Pallaniappa; Pallaniappa could acquire by survivorship.
Respondent Nagappa Chettiar adopted by Pallaniappa in 1941.
Appellant Villiammi Achi is widow of Pallaniappa; Nachiammai Achi (dead) was Pallaniappa's mother.
Pallaniappa died on September 16, 1956, after Hindu Succession Act, 1956 came into force.
Suit by respondent against appellant and others for two-thirds share of properties left by Pallaniappa, for separate possession after partition.
Trial court decreed suit giving two-thirds to respondent, one-sixth each to appellant and Nachiammai's representative.
Madras High Court in Appeal No. 347 of 1958 dismissed appellant's appeal on July 13, 1962.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether there was election by Pallaniappa to take under his father's will and if so, whether the respondent would be bound by it.
Whether Pallaniappa threw the entire property into the family hotch-pot after adoption of the respondent, making it joint family property.

petitioner_arguments.text: Pallaniappa's conduct in obtaining probate and carrying out will terms amounted to election; residue became his absolute property; respondent acquired no interest by adoption in 1941; no joint family property at Pallaniappa's death; respondent bound by election under S.180 Indian Succession Act.

respondent_arguments.text: No election by Pallaniappa as he had title by survivorship irrespective of will; S.180 does not apply; even if election, respondent not bound as his interest independent of father upon adoption.
Pallaniappa threw entire property into family hotch-pot after adoption, making it joint family property.

court_reasoning.text: No election under S.180 as Pallaniappa would get property by survivorship anyway; no benefit derived from will requiring choice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Election arises only where legatee must choose between own property willed away and testator's property given by will.

court_reasoning.text: Even assuming election, father's will cannot change joint family property character in son's hands; son takes interest by birth independent of father under Mitakshara law.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Adopted son acquires independent interest in joint family property upon adoption.

court_reasoning.text: Unnecessary to consider blending into hotchpot as election issue resolves in respondent's favour.

holdings.text: No election by Pallaniappa; even if any, does not bind adopted son whose interest is independent; properties remain joint family property.

precedents_cited.case_name: Halsbury's Laws of England, Third Edition, Vol. 14, p. 588, para 1091
precedents_cited.relevance: Explains doctrine of election: legatee must choose between own property and benefits under will.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mulla's Hindu Law, Thirteenth Edition, p. 249, para 223
precedents_cited.relevance: Share on partition of ancestral property is ancestral as regards male issues.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mulla's Hindu Law, Thirteenth Edition, p. 251, para 224
precedents_cited.relevance: Son takes interest in ancestral property by birth, independent of father.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Succession Act, 1925
statutes_cited.relevance: Enunciates doctrine of election; does not apply as no choice required.

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Succession Act, 1956
statutes_cited.relevance: Came into force before Pallaniappa's death.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upholds High Court and trial court decrees; respondent entitled to two-thirds share as joint family property; appeal by special leave dismissed.
outcome.relief_granted: Preliminary decree for partition confirming two-thirds share to respondent, one-sixth each to appellant and Nachiammai's representative.

key_quotes.text: "election under s. 180 would only arise where the legatee derives some benefit from the will to which he would not be entitled except for the will."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning why no election applies.

key_quotes.text: "the right which the son takes at his birth in the ancestral property is wholly independent of his father."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A father cannot turn joint family property into absolute property of his son by merely making a will."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Will does not alter property character.
